article.headline: LSU 68, New Orleans 60
article.story: NEW ORLEANS (AP) -- LSU's Jaime Lloreda refused to let early foul trouble stop him from making a difference for LSU. Lloreda scored 14 points, including nine in the final eight minutes, and grabbed three late offensive rebounds that preserved LSU's 68-60 victory over New Orleans on Monday night. Lloreda was forced to the bench with 1:44 remaining in the first half after picking up his third foul, and remained on the bench through the first four and a half minutes of the second half. Even after his return, Lloreda struggled to get involved in the offense, scoring just five points until the game's final eight minutes. "Jaime was frustrated that he wasn't touching the ball as much, and I got on him a little bit," LSU coach John Brady said. "But as a coach, I don't mind (the frustration) as long as they go back out and play." Lloreda finished with 12 rebounds, four offensive. "I was starting to get real frustrated because I wasn't getting the ball," Lloreda said. "I just decided to go hard to the boards, because that's the only way." Brandon Bass led LSU (12-1) with 18 points, while Antonio Hudson added 11. Johnell Smith led the Privateers (7-7) with 19 points and Bo McCalebb added 17. Trailing 49-39 with just over 10:30 remaining, McCalebb hit a 3-pointer, sparking a 10-0 run for the Privateers that tied the game. Lloreda's free throw gave LSU a 50-49 lead. Back-to-back jumpers from Hudson increased the lead to five, and then a Bass dunk after a steal by Darrel Mitchell extended the lead to 60-52 with 3:34 left. UNO was within 61-57 with 1:55 to go, but a tip-in by Lloreda after a missed free throw put the game away for LSU. "Big time players step up and win games when it's crunch time, and he (Lloreda) is a big-time player," New Orleans coach Monte Towe said. "I'm sure our kids were trying, but he's just a little bit stronger, bigger and maybe a little bit tougher than some of our guys."
